statement.text: Trash foot (atheroembolism) results from cholesterol and plaque debris embolization to distal small vessels, causing painful digital ischemia with preserved proximal pulses, often iatrogenic from endovascular procedures.
statement.formal: Etiology: Cholesterol crystal embolization from proximal atheroma; Presentation: Blue toes, livedo reticularis, preserved pulses; Treatment: Prevent further embolization, antiplatelet therapy, supportive care

explanation.intuition: When working on atherosclerotic arteries, pieces of plaque can break off and travel downstream, clogging tiny arteries in the toes. The toes turn blue and painful while the main pulses stay normal - because the blockage is in vessels too small to feel.
explanation.key_insight: Preserved pedal pulses with blue toes = think atheroembolism. The problem is in the microvasculature, not the large arteries.
explanation.technical_details: Atheroembolism (trash foot, cholesterol embolization syndrome) occurs when atherosclerotic debris dislodges from proximal aortic or arterial plaques and travels to small distal vessels. Unlike thromboembolism, these cholesterol crystals and calcific debris lodge in vessels <200 microns and cannot be removed. Triggers include endovascular procedures (catheter manipulation), vascular surgery, and anticoagulation (unmasking ulcerated plaques). Clinical features include painful blue toes, livedo reticularis, preserved proximal pulses, and renal or GI involvement in systemic cases. Prevention is paramount as treatment options are limited.
common_misconceptions: Blue toes with good pulses means adequate perfusion - FALSE, microembolization causes ischemia
Anticoagulation helps atheroembolism - FALSE, may worsen by unmasking plaques
Atheroembolism can be removed with thrombectomy - FALSE, debris is in microvessels
Only occurs during aortic procedures - FALSE, can occur with any proximal manipulation

mechanism.source: Atherosclerotic plaque in aorta, iliac, or femoral arteries
mechanism.emboli: Cholesterol crystals, calcific debris, platelet aggregates

inflammatory_response.result: Ongoing ischemia even after initial event

clinical_presentation.key_feature: Preserved pedal pulses despite digital ischemia

systemic.renal: Acute kidney injury from renal artery embolization

diagnosis.clinical: Classic triad: blue toes + preserved pulses + recent vascular procedure

biopsy.finding: Cholesterol clefts (biconvex crystals dissolved in processing)

procedural: Avoid crossing severely diseased aorta when possible
medical: Avoid unnecessary anticoagulation in at-risk patients

acute.remove_source: If ongoing source identified (e.g., mobile thrombus)

surgical.source_exclusion: Aortic surgery or EVAR to exclude source (rare)

definition.@value: Digital ischemia from microembolization of atherosclerotic debris to small distal vessels, characterized by blue toes with preserved proximal pulses.

sources.reference: Systematic reviews on cholesterol embolization syndrome

learning_objectives: Recognize the clinical presentation of atheroembolism
Explain why pulses are preserved despite digital ischemia
Implement prevention strategies during vascular procedures
Apply appropriate medical and surgical management
clinical_pearls: Blue toes + normal pulses = think atheroembolism
Prevention is key - once it happens, treatment is supportive
Statins stabilize plaques and may prevent recurrence
